text: And the waters covered their enemies: there was not one of them left.
text_kjv: And the waters covered their enemies: there was not one of them left.
text_niv: The waters covered their adversaries;not one of them survived.
text_esv: And the waters covered their adversaries; not one of them was left.
text_nlt: Then the water returned and covered their enemies;not one of them survived.
text_msg: Then the waters flowed back on their oppressors;there wasn't a single survivor.
text_nasb: The waters covered their adversaries; Not one of them was left.
context: Psalm 106 is a historical psalm, recounting Israel's repeated rebellion and God's persistent faithfulness during the Exodus and wilderness wanderings. Verse 11 specifically references the climax of the Exodus narrative: the parting of the Red Sea (or Yam Suph, often translated as Sea of Reeds). The Israelites, having been miraculously led out of Egypt, found themselves trapped between Pharaoh's advancing army and the impassable sea. In desperation, they cried out to the Lord. God, through Moses, parted the waters, creating a dry path for the Israelites to cross. Pharaoh's army, in pursuit, followed them into the seabed. However, once the Israelites had safely reached the other side, God released the waters, engulfing the entire Egyptian army. This event was not merely a military victory but a dramatic demonstration of God's power and his commitment to his covenant with Israel. The Egyptians' polytheistic religion was mocked; their gods were powerless against Yahweh. The completeness of the destruction – 'not one of them left' – emphasizes the totality of God's victory and the finality of Israel's deliverance. This was a foundational event in Israel's history, shaping their national identity and solidifying their belief in Yahweh as their savior and protector. The psalm serves as a reminder of this pivotal moment and underscores the importance of remaining faithful to God, despite past failures.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 106:11 highlights several crucial aspects of God's character and his relationship with humanity. First, it demonstrates God's power over creation. The parting and closing of the Red Sea are not mere coincidences but acts of divine intervention, showcasing God's ability to manipulate natural forces for his purposes. This power is wielded for the salvation of his people and the destruction of their enemies. Secondly, the verse underscores God's justice. Pharaoh and the Egyptian army were not simply victims of a natural disaster; they were punished for their oppression of the Israelites and their defiance of God's will. The phrase 'not one of them left' emphasizes the completeness of God's judgment. This verse also foreshadows the ultimate triumph of good over evil. The Red Sea event serves as a type or symbol of future deliverances, including the ultimate victory over sin and death through Jesus Christ. Just as God rescued Israel from slavery in Egypt, he offers salvation to all who believe in him. Finally, the verse emphasizes the importance of remembrance. By recalling this event, the psalmist reminds the Israelites (and us) of God's faithfulness and the consequences of disobedience. It serves as a warning against repeating the mistakes of the past and encourages a life of gratitude and obedience to God's commands. The completeness of the Egyptians' demise also points to the finality of God's judgment on unrepentant sin.
application: Psalm 106:11 holds profound practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it reminds us of the reality of spiritual warfare. Just as the Israelites faced a physical enemy in the Egyptians, we face spiritual adversaries in the form of sin, temptation, and the forces of evil. This verse assures us that God is powerful enough to overcome these enemies. We can trust in his protection and provision as we navigate the challenges of life. Secondly, the verse encourages us to trust in God's timing and his methods. The Israelites likely felt trapped between the sea and the army, but God had a plan. Similarly, we may face seemingly impossible situations, but we must trust that God is working behind the scenes to bring about his purposes. It's important to remember that God's ways are not always our ways, and his timing may not align with our expectations. Thirdly, Psalm 106:11 calls us to remember God's past faithfulness. When we face doubt or fear, we can reflect on the times when God has delivered us in the past. Remembering his past acts of grace can strengthen our faith and give us hope for the future. Just as the Israelites were reminded of the Red Sea deliverance, we can remind ourselves of God's faithfulness in our own lives. Fourthly, the verse warns us against complacency and pride. The Israelites quickly forgot God's miraculous deliverance and turned away from him. We must be vigilant to avoid the same mistake. We must continually cultivate a spirit of humility and gratitude, acknowledging our dependence on God's grace. Finally, the total destruction of the enemy serves as a powerful symbol for the completeness of God's salvation. When we come to Christ, our old life is washed away, and we are made new. We can live in freedom and victory, knowing that God has conquered our enemies and secured our eternal destiny.
prayer: Sovereign God, we stand in awe of your power and majesty, remembering the miraculous deliverance at the Red Sea. Thank you for your unwavering faithfulness to your people, even in the face of their rebellion. Forgive us for our own forgetfulness and tendency to stray from your path. Help us to remember your past acts of grace in our lives and to trust in your provision for the future. Strengthen our faith, Lord, that we may stand firm against the spiritual battles we face. Give us the courage to trust in your timing and your methods, even when we cannot see the way forward. Fill us with humility and gratitude, so that we may always acknowledge your sovereignty in our lives. We praise you for the completeness of your salvation, knowing that you have conquered our enemies and secured our eternal destiny. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Remembering the Red Sea crossing reinforces faith in God's power and faithfulness. It serves as a historical testament to His deliverance and a warning against forgetting His blessings, thus avoiding repeating past mistakes of disobedience.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is it important to remember the story of the Red Sea crossing?

faqs.answer: The verse illustrates God's justice by depicting the consequences of Pharaoh's oppression and defiance. The complete destruction of the Egyptian army demonstrates God's judgment against those who oppose His will and mistreat His people.
faqs.question: Q2: How does Psalm 106:11 relate to God's justice?

faqs.answer: Yes, the Red Sea crossing can be viewed as a type or foreshadowing of the salvation offered through Jesus Christ. Just as Israel was delivered from slavery, Christians are delivered from sin and death through Christ's sacrifice.
faqs.question: Q3: Can the Red Sea crossing be seen as a foreshadowing of Jesus Christ?

faqs.answer: The phrase 'not one of them left' emphasizes the totality and decisiveness of God's victory over the Egyptians. It underscores the completeness of the deliverance for Israel and the finality of God's judgment on their enemies.
faqs.question: Q4: What does 'not one of them left' emphasize in Psalm 106:11?

faqs.answer: Apply the message by trusting in God's power to overcome challenges, remembering His past faithfulness, and avoiding complacency. Acknowledge God's sovereignty, cultivate humility, and trust in His timing and methods in all situations.
faqs.question: Q5: How can I apply the message of Psalm 106:11 in my daily life?
